s.text: One of Gardner's missions is to apply his work to the classroom, since he believes schools are designed by people excelling in linguistic and logical-mathematical intelligences to reward people who share those intelligences.

One of Gardner's missions is to apply his work to the classroom, since he believes schools are designed by people excelling in linguistic and logical-mathematical intelligences to reward people who share those intelligences.

He believes an intelligence is the ability to "solve problems or create products" in a way that society values--that having it must have conferred an evolutionary advantage to us, and that there is biological evidence for it.
Gardner says, "Common sense, self-observation, and talking to others should suffice to tell you what is distinctive about your mind."
I recommend taking the Temperament Sorter II and ignoring the Character Sorter, which I found confusing and not particularly accurate.
According to D'Adamo, eat the right foods for your type and your immune system will be strengthened and you'll lose weight.
Among living hunter-gatherers, he says, most of their calories come from vegetable matter, because bagging game is difficult.
This notion lives on in our language today.
Understanding our areas of strength and weakness, he says, can provide more self-awareness and help users move to a "higher level of skill."
Understanding our areas of strength and weakness, he says, can provide more self-awareness and help users move to a "higher level of skill."
If you know your blood type, it is easy.
You already know your own status and it's easy to ask others, "Do you have siblings?"
For example, I'm an NT, which makes me a Rational, therefore naturally curious, restless, and doubting.
For example, I'm an NT, which makes me a Rational, therefore naturally curious, restless, and doubting.
For example, I'm an NT, which makes me a Rational, therefore naturally curious, restless, and doubting.

But D'Adamo's promotional materials do quote Elizabeth Hurley (Type O), in a Cosmopolitan interview, saying she read D'Adamo's "absurd book," followed his plan, and "lost an astounding amount of weight."
Recently, like a breakaway republic, Gardner has added an eighth intelligence and is considering a ninth.
Since I felt that his theory left out people who are skilled at the use of the senses of taste and smell, I lobbied him to add culinary intelligence.
